segments.text: Okay, now, would you list the important events you think of in terms of organization that occur that change the nature of oceanography?
Well, scientifically, from the scientific point of view, the first that I can, in my time, was the writing of the book The Oceans by Spherdrup, Johnson, and Fleming.
The second was due to his

And Sproul's forethought, getting 15 and more picked young scientists trained who became head or leaders in practically every oceanographic institution in the country and was the nucleus on which the scientific development could be built.
The third was the Office of Naval Research Organization for the purpose of supporting research in the government.
Organization-wise, oh, and then you must put into consideration the work of Revelle and Bennett and Wakelin and all of that group

and the expansion of oceanography in such things as the International Geophysical Year, and following on down through those projects to the International Decade of Ocean Exploration, which is now going on.

Also important, both scientifically and organization-wise, was the Informal Coordinating Committee within the Navy, which became the Interagency Oceanographic Committee, which became Wenck's commission under Humphrey toward the last.
The TANOC plans put out by ONR, the establishment under Harrison Brown

the great work of defining what oceanography should do, the National Committee on Oceanography, NASCO, the follow-through of the Stratton Report, which unfortunately met a political situation which was not fruitful.
These were some of the milestones, as I saw them,
Now, finally, if you should like to be remembered for your major contribution to oceanography, what would you choose?
That was a good program, man.
